title: Projectile point, serrated
creator: Donald Crabtree
description: A relatively small and fragile piece, this traditional projectile point form has been elevated to pure art with the addition of serrations along the margins.
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Comparative Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho
rights: These files are provided for non-commercial use with proper attribution (CC BY-NC), with copyright held by the University of Idaho. For other uses, please contact the Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho.

title: Experimental core
creator: Donald Crabtree
description: Later in his life, Crabtree once again became fascinated with the technical aspects of artifact production and replication, which is evident in this image, an example of the debitage (or debris) created in the process of flintknapping.
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Comparative Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho
rights: These files are provided for non-commercial use with proper attribution (CC BY-NC), with copyright held by the University of Idaho. For other uses, please contact the Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho.

title: Biface
creator: Donald Crabtree
description: Dating to 1920-1930, this piece is one of Crabtree’s earliest creations and shows that even at such a young age, he already had a deep understanding of stone tool manufacturing.
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Comparative Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho
rights: These files are provided for non-commercial use with proper attribution (CC BY-NC), with copyright held by the University of Idaho. For other uses, please contact the Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho.

title: Projectile point, eccentric
creator: Donald Crabtree
description: This piece show Crabtree’s ability to balance art with science as any flintknapper knows that notching a tool or pressing out sections, as seen here, is an opportunity to shatter the stone as each extension is an unsupported area susceptible to breakage.
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Comparative Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho
rights: These files are provided for non-commercial use with proper attribution (CC BY-NC), with copyright held by the University of Idaho. For other uses, please contact the Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho.
